summary: This is a court order from Judge Alison J. Nathan addressing the government's motion for clarification regarding cross-examination of pseudonymous witnesses and sketch artist depictions in the Ghislaine Maxwell criminal case. The order denies the government's request to limit cross-examination about witnesses' careers, upholding the defendant's Sixth Amendment rights.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case referenced in this court order.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The judge who issued this order, ruling on government motions regarding witness cross-examination and sketch artist procedures.

connections.description: Judge Nathan is presiding over the criminal case against Maxwell and issued this order regarding trial procedures.

events.title: Pretrial Conference
events.description: A pretrial conference was held where issues regarding witness cross-examination and sketch artist depictions were discussed.

events.title: Court Order Issued
events.description: Judge Nathan issued this order clarifying cross-examination rules for pseudonymous witnesses and ordering the government to submit a proposed order regarding sketch artist depictions.

events.title: Deadline for Government Submission
events.description: The government is ordered to submit a proposed order regarding sketch artist depictions of certain witnesses by this date.

locations: United States District Court Southern District of New York
keyFacts: The court denied the government's request to limit cross-examination about pseudonymous witnesses' careers, citing the defendant's Sixth Amendment right to meaningful cross-examination.
The court ruled that while specific employer names cannot be elicited, the type and genre of employment may be relevant to jury credibility assessments.
The government was ordered to submit a proposed order regarding sketch artist depictions of certain witnesses by November 18, 2021.
This document shows ongoing procedural disputes in the Ghislaine Maxwell trial regarding witness protection and defendant's rights.
The case referenced is United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell, case number 20-CR-330 (AJN) in the Southern District of New York.
